abstract: President Obama’s news conference was primarily focused on economic issues, including the bank bailout and bonuses at A.I.G., while there was little mention of foreign policy.
snippet: President Obama’s news conference was primarily focused on economic issues, including the bank bailout and bonuses at A.I.G., while there was little mention of foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Zeleny | 9:07 p.m.  Different times, indeed. For a while, I wondered whether Mr. Obama was almost hoping for a question about Iraq or Afghanistan — anything to turn the page from the economy. He did, though, seem to turn the page from the anger that had welled up over Wall Street bonuses. It remains an open question whether he made any headway persuading members of Congress about his ambitious budget. Perhaps we’ll find out tomorrow, when he visits Capitol Hill. But for now, it’s a wrap. Let’s go grab a drink, Helene.

headline.main: Live Blog: Obama’s News Conference

byline.original: By Jeff Zeleny and Helene Cooper

abstract: Beth Zak-Cohen, a student from Newark, N.J., weighs such issues as whether to go urban or rural, big school or small, pizza over mom’s cooking.
snippet: Beth Zak-Cohen, a student from Newark, N.J., weighs such issues as whether to go urban or rural, big school or small, pizza over mom’s cooking.
lead_paragraph: I’m indecisive. Honestly, that’s the crux of my college admissions experience. When applying, I couldn’t answer those questions you’re always asked — big or small, urban or rural, public or private — I really didn’t know what I wanted. In fact, as I went through my college search I found myself attracted to schools that fit many contradicting adjectives. I did however, decide two important things. I wanted a school close enough to a city, so that I could rush there if I wanted a good slice of pizza or the perfect outfit for a party. And I wanted to be close enough to home that I could go there if I was sick, or just wanted to visit (I am an only child, if that explains anything to those of you aching to get away). So, I decided on a list of schools. They fit a variety of categories — ivies, liberal arts schools, and state schools — but also fit the location criteria, had academic programs that interested me, and simply felt good. Yes, that magic “feeling” that tells you where you’re meant to be.

headline.main: The Envelope, Please: ‘Indecisive,’ With Conflicting Goals

abstract: Despite wait-listing and a rejection, Faithlynn Morris maintains a laid-back attitude.
snippet: Despite wait-listing and a rejection, Faithlynn Morris maintains a laid-back attitude.
lead_paragraph: This past Friday, I went online to get my admissions decision from Hamilton College, only to find that I had been wait-listed. When I checked my email two minutes later, I found that I’d also been wait-listed by Syracuse University and rejected altogether from Boston University. Oddly, I didn’t feel much of anything as I read the words, so I decided I would give myself the night to sleep on it and, hopefully, awake with, well, definitive emotions. But here I am, days later and still nothing. No tears, no screaming, no…anything. I feel perfectly fine, actually. I did get into Fordham, though, and I’m wondering if that, coupled with my Emerson acceptance, has something to do with this rather mellow mood. Hopefully, I can keep this laid-back attitude up as I get my financial aid packages.

headline.main: The Envelope, Please: ‘No Tears, No Screaming,’ Just Perspective

abstract: Jordan Mackey of Atlanta hasn’t received a thin envelope yet, but she wonders how she will react if she does.
snippet: Jordan Mackey of Atlanta hasn’t received a thin envelope yet, but she wonders how she will react if she does.
lead_paragraph: As April quickly approaches, my “Big Apple” dream seems to be drifting further and further away. Although I will not be greatly disappointed, considering the great schools that have already offered me a place to continue my education, I will feel some sense of failure. I know everyone reading just rolled their eyes.  How can she be so ungrateful? But give me a chance to explain myself.

headline.main: The Envelope, Please: A Student Wonders How She’ll Handle Rejection

abstract: Newt Gingrich, the former Speaker of the House, has converted to Catholicism.
snippet: Newt Gingrich, the former Speaker of the House, has converted to Catholicism.
lead_paragraph: Newt Gingrich, the former Speaker of the House, has converted to Catholicism. He has not said publicly why he converted, but his wife, Callista Bisek, is Catholic. Mr. Gingrich has been a Baptist since graduate school.

headline.main: Gingrich Gets (a New) Religion

abstract: Mixed emotions for Beth Zak-Cohen as letters from colleges arrive.

lead_paragraph: In the past few days, I’ve received every type of college letter. I was accepted at Vassar College, wait-listed at Haverford College, and rejected at Swarthmore College.

lead_paragraph: I gave a speech to an audience of mothers a few weeks ago, and one mom buttonholed me near the door.

abstract: Seattle’s passion for its new pro soccer team, the Sounders, reflects the region’s passion for the game and its conviction that it is not quite like the rest of America.
snippet: Seattle’s passion for its new pro soccer team, the Sounders, reflects the region’s passion for the game and its conviction that it is not quite like the rest of America.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE  When the new Swede arrived in the new Seattle, he needed no ax or fishing net, the tools of so many other Scandinavian immigrants who had come before. Instead he wore shorts, and when his name was called on his first day at work  “Freddie Ljungberg!”  28,000 people erupted.

headline.main: New Soccer Team Stokes Seattle’s Passion
headline.print_headline: An Alternative Sport For an Alternative City

abstract: President Obama traveled to Capitol Hill to bolster House Democrats as Congress began a politically charged budget debate.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama traveled to Capitol Hill on Monday evening to bolster House Democrats as Congress began a politically charged budget debate that will determine the president’s ability to pursue his broad domestic policy agenda.
